greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Fibonacci winding number: the number of 'mod n' operations in one cycle of the Fibonacci sequence modulo n.
comment: If pi(n) is the n-th Pisano number (A001175) then a(n) is usually about pi(n)/2 - and in any case a(n) > pi(n)/4.
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=2..10000
R. C. Johnson, Fibonacci Numbers and Resources.
M. Merca, Inequalities and Identities Involving Sums of Integer Functions, J. Int. Seq. 14 (2011) # 11.9.1.
formula: n*a(n) = sum{k=1..A001175(n)} fibonacci(k) mod n. [_Mircea Merca_, Jan 03 2011]
example: a(8)=4 because one cycle of the Fibonacci numbers modulo 8 is 0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5; 0, 5, 5; 2, 7; 1; - including 4 'mod 8' operations, each marked with a semi-colon.
mathematica: pp[n_] := For[k = 1, True, k++, If[Mod[Fibonacci[k], n] == 0 && Mod[Fibonacci[k + 1], n] == 1, Return[k]]];
results.author: R C Johnson (bob.johnson(AT)dur.ac.uk), Nov 19 2003
